page.title: 08Smarden Housing
page.content: Because of building restrictions and changes in agriculture farm buildings are now often converted: oast houses, redundant now that the hop trade is reduced, make attractive houses, their white cowls always preserved; and barns are being converted here, where building land is scarce. No ramshackle old cottages remain: dwellings once inhabited by working people have been restored and beautified by prosperous incomers keen to live in this renowned village; most young local people cannot afford a house in Smarden. Gardens are imaginatively planned and carefully maintained. The prefabricated houses built by the council in 1945 are bleak and unattractive but the mellower brick council estates now blend in with the older houses.
